answer_html: Here we are immediately done and so multiplying both sides above by -9 yields \(\displaystyle d \equiv -9 \equiv 55 \mod{64}\).
answer_latex:
Here we are immediately done and so multiplying both sides above by -9

hints_html:
Recall that in an RSA scheme, we need the system to satisfy

\(\displaystyle x \equiv x^{ed} \mod{n}\).

By Euler’s Theorem, we know that

\(\displaystyle x^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \mod{n}\)

So we seek to find a d satisfying \(\displaystyle ed \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(n)}\), that is, we need the inverse of e modulo \(\displaystyle \phi(n)\).
hints_latex:
Recall that in an RSA scheme, we need the system to satisfy

$\displaystyle x \equiv x^{ed} \mod{n}$.

By Euler's Theorem, we know that

$\displaystyle x^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \mod{n}$

So we seek to find a \emph{d} satisfying
$\displaystyle ed \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(n)}$, that is, we need the inverse
of \emph{e} modulo $\displaystyle \phi(n)$.
hints_raw:
Recall that in an RSA scheme, we need the system to satisfy

<math> \displaystyle 
x \equiv x^{ed} \mod{n}
</math>.

By Euler's Theorem, we know that 

<math> \displaystyle x^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \mod{n} </math>

So we seek to find a ''d'' satisfying <math> \displaystyle ed \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(n)} </math>, that is, we need the inverse of ''e'' modulo <math> \displaystyle \phi(n)</math>.
sols_html:
As stated in the hint, we seek to find a value of d such that

\(\displaystyle ed \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(n)}\)

Notice that \(\displaystyle \phi(n) = \phi(85) = \phi(5 \cdot 17) = \phi(5)\phi(17) = 4(16) = 64\). So we need to solve

\(\displaystyle 7d \equiv 1 \mod{64}\).

To do this, we use the Euclidean Algorithm.

\[\begin{aligned} 64 &= 7(9) + 1\end{aligned}\]

Here we are immediately done and so multiplying both sides above by -9 yields \(\displaystyle d \equiv -9 \equiv 55 \mod{64}\).
sols_latex:
As stated in the hint, we seek to find a value of \emph{d} such that

$\displaystyle ed \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(n)}$

Notice that
$\displaystyle \phi(n) = \phi(85) = \phi(5 \cdot 17) = \phi(5)\phi(17) = 4(16) = 64$.
So we need to solve

$\displaystyle 7d \equiv 1 \mod{64}$.

To do this, we use the Euclidean Algorithm.

\begin{align*}
64 &= 7(9) + 1
\end{align*}

Here we are immediately done and so multiplying both sides above by -9
yields $\displaystyle d \equiv -9 \equiv 55 \mod{64}$.
sols_raw:
As stated in the hint, we seek to find a value of ''d'' such that 

<math> \displaystyle ed \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(n)} </math>

Notice that <math> \displaystyle \phi(n) = \phi(85) = \phi(5 \cdot 17) = \phi(5)\phi(17) = 4(16) = 64 </math>. So we need to solve

<math> \displaystyle 7d \equiv 1 \mod{64} </math>.

To do this, we use the Euclidean Algorithm. 

<math>
\begin{align}
64 &= 7(9) + 1
\end{align}
</math>

Here we are immediately done and so multiplying both sides above by -9 yields <math> \displaystyle d \equiv -9 \equiv 55 \mod{64} </math>.
statement_html:
Suppose the public key for an RSA cryptosystem is \(\displaystyle (n,e) = (85,7)\) and the secret key is \(\displaystyle (85,d)\). Show that this cryptosystem is not secure by finding d.

Remarks: Recall that a message x is encoded by \(\displaystyle x \to x^{e} \mod{n}\) and a received message y is decoded by \(\displaystyle y \to y^{d} \mod{n}\). To make this cryptosystem secure, one needs to use a much larger n.
statement_latex:
Suppose the public key for an RSA cryptosystem is
$\displaystyle (n,e) = (85,7)$ and the secret key is
$\displaystyle (85,d)$. Show that this cryptosystem is not secure by
finding \emph{d}.

Remarks: Recall that a message \emph{x} is encoded by
$\displaystyle x \to x^{e} \mod{n}$ and a received message \emph{y} is
decoded by $\displaystyle y \to y^{d} \mod{n}$. To make this
cryptosystem secure, one needs to use a much larger \emph{n}.
statement_raw:
Suppose the public key for an RSA cryptosystem is <math> \displaystyle (n,e) = (85,7) </math> and the secret key is <math> \displaystyle (85,d)</math>. Show that this cryptosystem is not secure by finding ''d''.

Remarks: Recall that a message ''x'' is encoded by <math> \displaystyle x \to x^{e} \mod{n} </math> and a received message ''y'' is decoded by <math> \displaystyle y \to y^{d} \mod{n} </math>. To make this cryptosystem secure, one needs to use a much larger ''n''.
